summary: Background bovine rotavirus (BRV) is a non-enveloped dsRNA virus that causes neonatal calf diarrhea. the virus is a major agent of neonatal calf diarrhea that causes severe diarrhoea, dehydration, anorexia and death in newborn calves. strains are specialized membrane microdomains that are enriched in sphingolipids, cholesterol, SRC family protein kinases, and glycosylphosphatidylinositol (GPI)-anchored proteins. cholesterol-enrich membrane mircodomains play an important role in multiple stages of virus life cycle. intact cell membrane cholesterol was dispensable for the virus replication. however, virus assembly was in a cholesterol-dependent pathway. results suggest that cellular cholesterol is required for BRV attachment. cells were mock treated or treated with indicated concentrations of MCD for 30 min. at 1 h later, cell lysates were prepared by freeze-thaw. virus titers and viral mRNA levels were decreased in a dose-dependent manner. all experiments were performed three times, and the error bars indicated the standard deviation of three independent experiments. after virus attachment, the unbound BRV was removed, cells were treated with MCD at indicated time at 37°C. the inhibitive effect was partially reversed by cholesterol replenishment. compared to untreated cells, viral mRNA levels and protein amounts were not reduced. but virus titers were significantly decreased. BRV replication on MA-104 cells is independent of cell cholesterol. no inhibitory effect was detected by virus titration assay. it indicated cholesterol depletion had no effect on BRV attachment. cell
